title: Case Study: Ankle Sprain in a Young Athlete
clinical_history: A 19-year-old male soccer player presented to the clinic with a complaint of severe pain and swelling on the lateral aspect of his right ankle. He reported that during a soccer match 2 days ago, he landed awkwardly from a jump and heard a 'pop' sound. He was unable to bear weight on his ankle immediately after the injury and has been experiencing pain and stiffness since then. He has been applying ice and using crutches to ambulate.
aggrevating_factors: weight-bearing activities such as walking, running, and jumping; ankle dorsiflexion and inversion
picture: A 24-hour picture of the patient's ankle would show significant swelling and bruising on the lateral aspect, with difficulty bearing weight on the affected ankle.
easing_factors: rest, ice, compression, and elevation (RICE); oral pain medications
past_history: history of a similar injury to the left ankle 6 months ago, which was managed conservatively
medical_history: generally healthy, no significant medical conditions
medications: ibuprofen 400mg every 4-6 hours as needed for pain
personal_history: active young adult, plays soccer 3 times a week, and works part-time as a fitness instructor
imaging: X-rays of the ankle were taken in the emergency department and were negative for any fractures
